div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, SATURDAY, APRIL 7, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Head Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-904

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: Russian Attack Repulsed
div.p: Oyntoa reports that tho .Hpani-Ho lmve now advanced' '40 miles along tlio Tipling-Kirin rpml. Three Russian columns of all arms attacked CliineliSrfiTrv, to tbo west of Hie railway, dtmi'g the afternoon of the 3rd tost. They approached within 400 metres. The Hii-mhus wore repulsed in the evening. Their I —nro estimated at 200. The Japanese lost

div.head: MAN ARRESTED AT TSARSKOE SELO
div.p: It is reported here that a.man, disguised as a colonel of Cossacks, entered the Palace at Tsarskoe Selo on Monday during the recoption of officers. He was arrested. Two small bombs were found on him.

div.head: Germany and Morocco
div.p: t is- understood in well-informed circles that Germany desires to' settle the Morocco question by means of an iutornational confe- rence.

The'German Ambassador here callod ut the' War Department, and loft a memorandum with Mr. Taft stuting that Germany will stand io'ut for the “open door” in Morocco as well as in tho Far East, and for the preservation ol tlio “status quo” and the saleguarding of the commercial relations of all nations. France was n^t mentioned iu the memorandum. The latter has been communicated to President Roosevelt

Tho German Minister at Tangier has been recalled. Doctor Rosen, tho negociator of the . recent treaty with Abyssinia, has been appoint- ed his successor. (Reuter. Army'of Occupation.—After all the tally and commotion1 about the reduction of the Army of Occupation in Egypt, it may surprise our readers to learn that the total reduction up to date, amounts to about three hundred officers and men.

div.head: King Victor
div.p: King Emmanuel paid a visit and lunched ‘ with the Emperor -William on board tho "HoLenzolierh." Signor Tittoni and the Qer man Ambassador were present. The Kaiser is returning the visit on board an Italian warship.
King Victor Emmanuel and Emperor Wil- liam toasted their friendship and tire cause of peace based qp the alliance.

div.head: King of France
div.p: President Loubet met King Edward’s train at Pierrefitto and accompanied his Majesty hero. Tboy greeted each other quite in an informal manner like two personal friends. Although tho meeting was mooted prior to the Emporor William's visit to Tangier, it is regarded everywhere as au immistakeable reaffirmation of> the “entente,” with special reference to Germany’s interposition iu Morocco.

M. Loubet got into tho train at Pierrefitto station and accompanied King Edward as far as Paris. The interview was very cordial. The police discovered some military uni- forms and rifles. It is believed there is a plot.

div.head: Local and General
div.p: The Brindisi Mail will olose at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 8.30 a.m. on Sunday. Quarantine restrictions, as against plague, are now applied in Egyptian ports to arrivals from Newcastle

Suez Canal.—9 vessels passed through the Canal on tho 4th inst, 3 of which wore British, 2 German, 1 Italian,-! Dutch, 1 Kus inn, 1 Turkish.Thoday’s receipts wore frs. 207,8-10.93, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 1,365,203.43.

British Recreation Club.—We understand that yesterday the Government gave the Cairo British Recreation Club written notice to hand back their ground within six months. The Government was’ only bound to give two months’ notice.

Mixed Appeal Court.—The case of the heirs of tho Into Advocate Rossetti v. Omar Bey Sultan and Mr. N. Soipliui will bo heard on the 12th inst., boliJro the Alixod Appeal Court. Maitre Carton do Wiart will appear for the heirs and Maitres Lusena and Foruario for the defendants.

ET.C. Rates.—This morning, the negotia- tions between Sir John Denison Pender and the Egyptian Government in regard to the reduction of the cable rates to England were resumed. Sir John paid a brief visit to Alex- andria yesterday, returning to Cairo in the evening.

Fayoum Light Railway. — The local tri- bunal ot Mediuot ol-Fayoum has sentenced a station master of the Fayoum Light Railway Company to four months’ imprisonment for stealing goods from merchants who had sent merchandise to the station. The case brought by Mr. Davison agaiust the company has beou postponed.

Charity Fete.—The annual charity ffito in aid of the Conferouoo do Saint Vincout de Paul (houso-to-houso visitation of the poor) will take place to morrow at G.30 p.m. at the Jesuit Chapel. Tbo sorinou will be preaohed oy the Rev. Father Louis Poerroy, S. J., and the collection will bo mado by Mmes. Pierre Girard and. Ernest Eeman.

Saved el-Sadat'b Household.—The recent developments iu the family affairs of Sayed el- Sadat have caused a great deal of talk in native eiroles in Cairo. Not only Sofia Hanem, whoso marriage with Sheikh Aly Yousscf was an- nounced last year; aud her mother, but another wife of El-Sodat and her daughter have taken refuge at the houso of the Princes! Nazli lianem.

Summer Leave.—Those who arc contem- plating a journey homo this summer should uot fail to note the advantageous terms offered to residents by tho Orient-Pacific Line. Between May and October tho following reduced fares will be in force:—First class, Port Said to Til- bury, £16.16.0; .Port Said to Marseilles, £12. 12.0. Second-class, Port Said to Tilbury. £12.12. 0 ; Port Said to Marseilles, £9. 9. 0. These reduced fares are also subject to tho usual rebate for passongors returning on the line.

Garrison Church of 8t. George, Musta- pha Pasha.—The Right Rev, Bishop Morley, D.D., Archdeacon of the •Church of England in Egypt, will preach at the parade service at 11 a.m. on Sunday next, 9th inst., and after the service will administer the rite of Confir mation. There will be a full choral service, and the string band of the 2nd Royal Berk- shire Regiment, supplemented by the organ. The oolleotion will bo given to the New Organ Fund. Visitors will be cordially weloomed. There will be evensong and sermon at 6.80 p.m., when "The Story of the Crow” will bo song.

div.head: The Nile Dam and its task
div.p: Tho question-of raising the Nilo dam at Assouan is keenly exorcising the professional mind. Engineers, more especially those who have had experience of largo water schemes, are divided as to whothor or not the present barrage ought to be taxed with extra work, and it iB reassuring to find a voice raised here and there on the side of prudence and delay. We have interviewed Mr. Ewing Matheson, a well- knownmember of thelnstituteof Civil Engineers, and while expressing confidence in the nnited experience of the chief experts in this branch of the profession—men like Mossrs. Mansergh, Hawksley, and Bateman—ho said Sit Benjamin Baker would be well advised to lengthen the period of observations before tho present struc- ture of the dam was added to in any way. “The Nile dam,” said Mr. Matheson to our representative, “was no doubt designed for its present height of water, with a margin of safety, and to raise it to a considerable height means >oviving the old question of flooding the island of Philm over again, and matters of publio safety that are much more important. .It is impossible to foretell or conceivo the damage which would bo done if the dam were over- taxed."

Mr. Matheson cited the disastrous Roods at Sheffield and Johnstown, Pennsylvania, as instances of insufficient planning. "I visited Johnstown,” he said, "twelve months after the catastrophe, and saw traces even then of that terrible flood. Fifteen miles away from the scene of the buret, there wore locomotives swept aside and overturned, and it was all due to insufficient calculation, addod^to tho usual light-heartodness of the Americans in their dbnstructive undertakings.

The two main considerations in the proper working of a dam of this kind are the rush of wator and the height—tho ‘height’ being a technical expression for tho hydrostatic pres- sure. It is the rush of water which creates what we call the ‘scour,’ or attrition along the conduits or subterraneau passages; and it was wiih a' view to.preserve them that, in the Assouan case, they were paved for a certain portion. Sir Benjamin Baker's recent visit was to report on the working out of these calcula- tions, and as a result this pavement is to be extended. But it will be a matter for the most anxious consideration before tho dam is raised, as projected, merely to increase the area of irrigation purposes. Far better wait another year or two, and estimate wear and tear upon toe present construction.

"Are there any precedents f” we naked. "Yea, of one kind or another," was the reply, "and the experience in this class of work among British engineers all over tho world, as well as m work under British supervision, fortifies us against any novel theories or experimente.There have been just sufficient failures to bring them up to tho mark, and in the construction of masonry dams no possible precaution is now- nogleoted, oven where, as in tho case of the present construction at Leeds, the volume ol water is not to be compared with that of the Nile.

"Everything, depends upon the margin of safety as allowed originally. It must have entered iuto the minds of the designers that the dam might be raised or thiokeued later on; and it remained then to see that the dovetail- ing of the rock foundations wero sufficient for auy increase in superincumbent weight. Personally, I should advise waiting for another year or two, as I have said, balore considering additions involving perhaps 6lbs. extra pressure to the square inch of surfaco. The advantages to be gained are dwarfed iuto insignificance c impure! with the awful oxtent of the danger incurred

Tho following wero tho suggestions addressed to tho Government by tho members of the Genoral Assembly :— , 1. For tho creation of a Municipality at Cairo, by Sheikh el Demerdashi. 2. For the construction of a .railroad from Nag Hamadi to Edfou, the conversion of the Ramadi Canal to a Sufi canal, and the con- struction of an agricultural road from Abou Shousha to Esueh. 3. For the reform of teaching in tho kuttabs. 4. For the construction fif drains in Cairo and tho modification of Article 18 iu tho statutes referring to tho Genoral Assembly, by Sheikh Aly Youssef. ,6, For tho reform of irrigation in Upper Egypt, by Selem Bey Mashkour, Seir ol Nasr Boy Tantawi, Koraiem Bey Koraghi, and Diab Bey Abou Selim. 7. Establishment of a "Kantara” in the Damietta mouth of the Nile instead of build- ing up a sudd every year. . '/A. 8. 0. The race coupe will bo opon for galloping to-morrow morning from 6 to 9 o’clock. Greek Independence Day.—At 10 ojolock this morning a To Doom Mass was celebrated' at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral, Alexandria. Mr. Scotidis and the poreonnol of the Hellenic Consulate were present in full uniform and the President of the Commnnity, Mr. Benaohi. The leading members of tho Hollenio colony wore present, including Mr. Em. M. Sinadino, Sulvago, Zervudaobi, Dr. ValosaopOulo, etb. The oeremony ended with an appropriate sermon by the Patriarch Pbotioa. The band of 'the Pbilharmonio Soofoty played outside and then marched to tho Consulate, where a reoeption was held

div.head: Late Archbishop Bonfoli
div.p: The tolling of the faneral bell at St. Catherine's Cathedral last night announoed that already a year had elapsed since the death of Archbishop Gaudenzio Bonfigli. This mom- ing, a speoial service was held at the Cathedral, Pietro Magri’s requiem mass being sung by tho brothers of the Christian Schools, Arch- bishop Briante officiating. All the clerical orders of the city were represented, and grouped near the high altar were H. E. the Governor, several of the consuls, headed by the French Consol, etc. The service was of the most impressive character, and the large congregation, it oould be ^ seen, was deeply affected. The splendid Hiseremini mei especially was rendered with supremo pathos. At the close of the requiem, the celebrant, attended by his clergy, left the altar preoeded by the crucifix and acolytes, and went towards the catafalque for the absolu- tion,, the time the Christian Brothers sang Libera me. . This oeremony over the Archbishop went to St. Mark’s ohapel, where the mortal remains of tho .fata Archbishop Bonfigli are laid, and where a monument to his memory has been ereotod. Mr. Moriondo, president of the memorial committee, here address-' ed the Archbishop iu Italian, handing over the memorial to hisjordahip’s care. Archbishop Briante replied, thanking the committee for their beautiful gift to the church, which would always receive the most tender and reverent care.

The parchment containing a record of the ceremony and the names of the clergy con- nected with the chdrch, was then signed by the oonsuls present and read by the Pro-Vicar General Amadio Amato, to whoso initiative and untiring efforts the erection of the monu- ment is maiuly due, and who deserves the thanks of the Catholic community. » The members of the St. Catherine's Club kept order during the service admirably.

div.head: The Duke of the Abruzzl
div.p: _ H.R.H. tho Duke of the Abruzzi left for Cairo yesterday in company with the Marquis di Salvogo-Raggi and arrived there ot 7.25 p.m. The distinguished visitor at once proooeded to the Savoy Hotel His Royal Highness is expected to return to Alexandria either to- morrow afternoon or Sunday morning. The Italian colony will give a ball at tho New Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria, on Sunday next in honor of the Duke of the Abram. The officors of the "Liguria’’ and the Prince’s staff will attend.

div.head: Chronique Judicate
div.p: M. Dubrey.il dtoit employd depuis trois ana l’usiue do Mattel dos Suoreries et fiaftiuerie' d'Egypte; il a dtd lioenoid sans auoun avis jjrtelable a la date du 7 avril 1904'pour cause 1 ae" tin do fabricition ” ; il devalt cesser son sdtVwe'lo lo dvril et lbs Suoreries (ui oftraient ' sea i'ppoin'ie'ulbuts jusqu'k oette date; jiar la suite, la Socidtd a offert 21 livres. M. Dubreuil reclame k raUdlencffAl livres et k la suite de la'^redaction d’aneiA/tidcequ’iljnge diffama- foife il1 rbotoffie 50 livres it titre de dom- foagw-irttdrdte.

A la bktte Atra D4han‘pour la Socidtd a de- rriandb1 a!u Tribariald’inAttguYer une jurispru- donoe toat-it-fait nouvelle en matidre de con- trat de travail; il soutieut que o’estit l’employd qu'incdmbe le devoir de prouver leoaractdre intempestif da renvoi; en d'autres tonnes il vent mettre a la charge du demandeur de rap- porter une preuve ndgative puisque le renvoi intempestif est prdciadment celui qui est sans cause sdrieuse ni valkblek l’t!gard de 1’employd. Mtre Martino pour I’duiployd s’est dlevd eaergiquement coutie cette throne; o'est la Sooidtd qui floit savoir et qui est' tenue d’dta^ blir pour quellea reasons' elle a fenvoyd son employd; o'est elle qui, par lo fait du renvoi, clonne naissance a la cause du cou’flit qui va naltre entre 1’employeur et I’einployd et elle est, par oonsdquent, dans l'obligation de juati- fior qu’elle avait le droit de fairs naltre cette cause podr ddhapper dux responsabilitds qur en ddcoulent.

Les plaidoiriea se sont animdes lorsqu’il a dtd question d’une lettro dcrite par l’admi- nistration dos ohemius de fer dans des cir- ' Constances anormalos a la Sooidtd des Suoreries au sujet de M. Dubreuil. La Souidtd prdtend qu’elle a droit de verser au dossier toutcs les’ pidces nontenant des alldgations injurieuscs pour sos omploydd et quo sa rosponsabilitd du lait do oelto production ne peut naltre que s'il en est donnd lecture a laudience. Mtre Martino a protestd vivemdht contre cfl ; systime de defense; il est inadmissible que les / Suoreries essayent de justifier le'renvoi d’un c employd en lprbdtuunt au dossier des pidcos f dont elles reconnaissent si bien le caraotdre 1 diffamatoTro que lour avocat nose les lire k l’audiende. Par le fait de la mise au dossier, la1 piioe a re$u une publioitd suffisante aux tenues de la loi pour justifier la demande de dommages-intdrdta.

div.head: Mesopotamia
div.p: The Tigris enters its delta at Baled, near thesite of the ancient Opis, where were situated the famous weirs of antiquity and which were 'described by Tavernier. I used to think that these weirs were altogether artificial, bnt an examination of the site has made me think that they were natural bars of .vory hard conglomerate, as hard as. the compactest crys- talline limestone, which overlay stiff clay. The crests of the weirs wore probably artifi- cially raised. This conglomerate can bo seen to-day.along the left bank of the river from Samarra to nearly opposite Boled. It has a thickness of over ip metres at Samarra, and under it can be seen some 6 metres of stiff ~*any above the water’s edge of the Tigris. The conglomerate dips under the allurvum of the Tigris below Beled and its termination was in Probability a great cataract near Beled known .ally as "Sadd Nimrud,” or Nimrod’s dam. 'file Nahrwan and Dijail canals look out from above these weire^ .The Nahrwan canal was ruined by the Tigris changing its course, and the undermining and sweeping away of these great cataracts sealed the ruin of all the irrigation systems fed by the Tigris. From Beled to Bagdad the Tigris has a length of about 110 kilometres, and a width of from 4 kilometres to 350 'metres. Where the river is wide, it flows over a bed of shingle and has a velocity pf some 6 to 7 kilometres per hour. Navigation by sailing boats is impossible against the current.

From Bagdad to Gurnn,whore tho Tigris and Euphrates meet, the river has a length of 740 kilometres. The distance from Gnrna to Basra is 60 kilometres, and 100 kilometres further on is the Persian Gulf. Tho distances along the Tigris are therefore as follows . . ' From Beled to tho Sea J 1010 kilometres From Bagdad to Basra 800 „ From Bagdad to the Sea 900 „ After.leaving the rapids at Beled, the bed of tftj Tigris, like that of the Euphrates, is'every- where mud. The watere are yellow like those of the Tiber and the Euphrates. Bagdad is the real northern terminus of river navigation on the Tigris. It has taken, the place of the ancient Opis, which was further north

The following tables of very approximative mean heights of the Tigris at Bagdad will give a fair.idea of times for flood and low supply:— January February March - .April • May June July „ . August September October November December 2.00 3.00 '6.00^ ff.00 ■ 5.50 3.50 2.00 ■ 1.00 ’ 0.00, 0.00 1.50 1.00 1000 1600 3000 4000 3500 1500 1000 1500 o. metres per second.

div.head: Letter to editor
div.p: A QUEER GRAMMAR. To rta Editor of the Egyptian Gazette. Sir,—In reply to “Grammarian’s” lette.r in yesterday’s “Gazette,” I hive to inform him:— .(1) Not long before reviewing Dirr’s Arabic Grammar, the “Gazette” published my opinion of another grammar of the classical language, which was most flattering and which was afterwards shared by the editor of a well-known literary Arabic periodical inJJairo in his review of it (2) ’ Before sending in mf artiole on Dirr’s grammar I gave the book to a native friend (who is a competent Arabio scholar) to read and return to me with his opinion. He brought it after a few days and told me what he thought of it in fewer but severer words than I used. I then gave him my article to read and he approved of every word I said. Moreover, I have not yet met one who knew the book and did not share my opinion of it (3) Since sending my article to the "Ga- zette” 1 have learned that the book had been sent to an Euglish gentleman who is a well- known Arabic scholar, but although he refused to review it he marked here and there what he considered flagrant errors. The reason of his refusal is therefore not far to seek. . (4) I confirm every word I said in my review, but I cannot enter into any discussion with one who makes the ridioulous statement that it is grammatically correct to say el ingi- lyz tayiba because he means the English as a nation, and pretends that most of the other mistakes are obvious slips. (5) "Grammariau” has the fault of more than one other resident in the country who no sooner- picks up? a few words of Arabio (and before he could write a sentence correctly without the aid of some one else) than be rushes.to the press with a wonderful grammar of his own. It would have been better for “Grammarian” to study the language for many more years before venturing to write a book dealing with it (6) "Grammarian’’ will have to get all the , mistakes I pointed out, and many more, cor- ; need before the book ceases to be called a . "queer’’ grammar.. As regards his personal reference to me, there is no need for me to reply, as this sort of controversial method is beneath oontempt.— Yours very truly, The Whiter of the Review.

div.head: SUDAN EXPLORATION SHARES
div.p: Mr. Justice Kekewich in the Chancery Divi- sion on,Tahsday w§ek continued the hearing of the notion in whioh'Dr. Robert William Eelkin Rued the Palmerston Industrial and Finance Corporation, Ltd., and Mr. Alfred -Bridge, a company promoter, of-15, Cockspur-street, W., claiming rescission of an agreement to take 800 shares in the Sudan Exploration, Ltd., and a declaration that defendants were liable to indemnify the plaintiff in respect of all expen- ses incurred by him in relation to the transac- tion, or in the alternative damages for alleged misrepresentation. The corporation denied that its policy or business was controlled by Bridge, and did not admit that the representations alleged to have been made by him were made on behalf of the corporation or with its know- ledge. The.defendant Bridge pleaded that if he did. make any representations or statements concerning the present or future value of the shares they were bona fide expressions of opi- nion. Defendant Bridge counter-claimed againit the plaintiff for alleged misrepresentation.— Mr. P. Ogden Lawrence, K. C. and Mr. J; H. Simmons appeared for plaintiff, Mr. Ashton Cross for the Palmerston Corporation, and Mr. W. J. L Ambrose for Mr. Bridge. Plaintiff, continuing his evidence, said that up to the issue of the writ in this action he had never received a certificate for or transfer of the 800 shares in the . Sudan Exploration, Ltd.

In cross-examination by Mr. Ashton Cross, for the Palmerston Corporation, plaintiff said he knew the property whioh the Siidan Explo- ration had been formed to acquire. From his knowledge of the country witness believed the company's property to be valuable. Ho wa3 anxious to g|t some Sudan sbures if he could pay cash for them. The 10$. nominal shares could not be obtained for less than £1. Ho Btill believed in tho success of the Sudan Company if it was well managed. Mr. Ashton Cross said he agreed that the Palmerston Corporation sold the shares to Dr. Felkip and those shares had been delivered. Plaintiff, >n auswer to counsel, said ho be- lieved that the 800 shares were in the Sudan Company's hands' for transfer. In cross-examination by ' Mr. Ambrose, plaintiff said he understood that the Palmerston Corporation was to put the shares on the mar- ket at-£2 when the pooling-arrangement came to an end. He always understood that Bridge was actiug for the Palmerston Corporation. This concluded plaintiff's case, and Mr. Ashton Cross, submitting that ho case had been made out against the corporation, called Mr. Allred Bridge, who described himself as a director of. the Palmerston Corporation, of which,he said,tho plaintiff also beoamo a direc- tor. When the question of the Sudan Explora- tion shares was uuder discussion, plaintiff said that if he went into the matter ho should want a share of the profits, and witness then told him he had better become a director. Plaintiff, said witness, worked hand-in-hand with him in the Sudan matter, and advised the corporation to take up the shares. Witness denied that he ever made any representations to induce plaintiff to go into the share transaction, and he said that Dr. Felkin must have understood the whole transaction.

Cross-examined by Mr. Lawrence, witness said that he was a company promoter, and prior to his going to Cockspur-street he carried on business at 8, Union-court, FC., where he promoted a number of companies. May I take it that, all the companies you promoted oome to grief?—No.—Witness men- tioned the Pan-African Syndicate, Ltd., and the London and Provincial Dairy Company as suocossful promotions. Witness denied that at the time he left'Union-courtoxocutions were out against him at his office and at his house at Surbiton. Wore there any baukruptcy petitions present- ed against you ?—Yes. May I tako it that altogether 8, Union-court, got too hot for yon at tho time you migrated to the West End ?—No, not at all.—Witness said he sometimes advertised for directors willing to invest It was not true to suggest that witness was the Palmerston Corporation. He agreed that there was no entry in the mi- nute-books concerning the agreement with tho plaintiff. At the date of the signing of the bill by the plaintiff witness admitted that the only transfer of Sudan shares to the Palmer ston Corporation was one for 600 shqres. They had, however,’ made arrangements to acquirejurther shares.

div.head: Sports and Play
div.p: The abovo teams met at Abbassieh xm Wednesday last. Both teams hold a good record. The K.R.R’s, it seems, have not been defeated sinoe 1902, whereas the representatives of the Shamrook have only been beaten onoe in some sixtyodd matches,60 a good game was expected. The pitch was in splendid order as the Irishmen took the field in the following order : Goal, Dadgeon ; backs, Shanks and Reid ; halves, Millar, Nixon, and Smyth ; forwards, Todd, Hutton, Cunningham, Fallon, and Walsh. The Rifles won the spin of the coin and defended the city goals. There would be almost 900 spectators present when Cunningham commenced operations.. The opening minutes proved sensational as the Inuiskillings bom- barded the Rifles’ goal for fully five minutes. The custodian clearing the Rifles now broke away per Bibbleton, but Smyth robbed and returned. Todd getting possession centred well bnt Fallon sent behind. On the kick-off tho Rifles took play towards Dudgeon, but the latler was not to be oanght napping and cleared in Gillispie’s best style. At this stage the referee (a sergeant of the K.KR.’s) had occasion to retire owing to a misunderstanding of the roles, Mr. MoKenzie, Royal Engineers, filling the vacanoy (amid cheers). On play being resumed Cunningham got away and sent across to Todd, who outwitted two opponents and seut strongly into goal, where Fallon headed over the bar. Flay remained in midfield, until Fallon broke away, but when in a good position ho was! fouled by Bibbleton. A fight ensued, both players being oantioned. The Rifles’ right wiug now got away but Smyth intercepted and returned. Some very spirited play ’took place around the Rifles’ goal. At last, however, the custodian cleared. The Irishmen were now ’ having the best of matters and a shot of Cunningham's deserved a better fate. A free against the Green and Buff Brigade proved unproductive. It was close on half-timo as Hutton gave the Dark Greens’ defence some trouble. Half-time now arrived with the repre- seratives of the Shamrock pressing for all they were worth,but there was no score yet on either side.

After the usual refreshments both teams took tho field. The first thing noticeable was a great sprint by Todd. The ball, however, found touch. The Rifles now took play in hand, but Smith robbed the right wing -time after time. A corner to the Rifles looked ridrie too rosy for the Green and Buff Brigade, HoWeker Nixon cleared and the InniskUliugs were seen fio advantage. Walsh, however, ran the ball ovet tho liue. On the kick off Bibbleton got away, on his own, but Smith was on his track aneb blocked his passage once more. Not to be deniod, the Rifles got down towards Dudgeon and scored, but Johnny Bibbleton was given offside. On resuming, Millar got away on his own, and alter dodging a couple of opponents sent across to Cunningham, who had a good try for goal. The Rifles now pulled themselves togother and worked their way down towards Dudgeon but Nixon and Smith were not to be beaten so easily and play was once more trans- ferred, when Hutton got well away and gave to Todd, who aont in a "daisy cutter” to tho Custodian, who fell on the ball but too late, as Fallou gut the ball at his toe and into the net it went, drawing first blood for the Innis- killings amidst deafening cheers. Oa the ball being centred the K.RR’s got away but’ Reid returned the ball. Great was the excitement that now prevailed (at this stage Mion was injured and had to retire). Both teams were now playing a most determined and very hard game. If anything, the Inniskillingswere having tho best of matters at this stage. The shield holders were playing a fine combination game. It was a treat to watoh the five forwards play so woll considering tho circumstances under which they were placod. It was now wearing np to full'time as Walsh missed the much desired spot by inches. Shortlyafterthereferee’s whistle sounded for full time, leaving the Inniskillings winners of one of the most exciting games that ever took place in Cairo, and still undefeated. Final result 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers*-! Goal. 1st King’s Royal Rifles—Nil

div.p: La Mnnicipalito d'Alexandrie ddsirerait pour sea bureaux, un noinbro de nouveaux stagiaires ne ddpassant pas quatro pour, le moment Les conditions requises \sont la connaissanco Scribe et parlte des langobs framjaiso et arabe, un certificat de bonne eondnite et one santo nor- male. Les stagiaires serviront pendant six mois au maximum sans traitoment et recevront ensuite s’ils ont donn6 satisfaction trois livres par mois jnsqn’h oe qn’un poste dans les cadres vienne h devenir vacant Les demande8 pour cea postes seront admisea jusqu'au -12 Avril 1906. Un avis nltdrieur indiquera le jour et l'heure oh le ooneoure aura lien it la Municipality parmi les postulants dont les demandes auront eto aoceptoes.

La Mnnicipalite met en adjudication la four- niture et repandage de 720 mfetres onbes de ohakf A la route do Mojitazah; Le cautionnementest fix6 A L.E. 20. Le cahier des charges est d^posd au Bureau de la Voirie oh il peut fitre consults par les intoress^s tous les jours de 9 L A midi,les jours f^rids exoeptes. Les off res dovront fitre adressdos sous pli caoheto A Monsieur l’Administratour do la Municipalito avant le 11 oonrant Elies pourront dgalement fitro ddposdes en stance de laDyldgation le mSme jour A 5h.p.m. L’enveloppe devra fin outre porter la men- tion r "Soomission pour fonrnitnre de Chakf." Le cautionnement ou le re^u d’une banque d'aprfis les conditions du cahier des oharges, devra fit re remis sdparfiment au Servioe de la Comptabilitfi Gfinfirale avant 1’oaverture des offres et an plus tard le 11 courant A midi. Tonte offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions oi-despus sera ficartoe. L’Administrateur,
